head.title: How to Create 30 Million Jobs in Eight Years; Poverty's Gains

hedline.hl1: How to Create 30 Million Jobs in Eight Years; Poverty's Gains

block.p: ''The President's Night in the Sun'' (editorial, Aug. 14), which summed up President Reagan's term in office on the eve of the Republican National Convention, presents a rosier picture of the economy than the Reagan Administration deserves. Since January 1981, 18 million new jobs have been created. Of these, three-quarters have been in the two lowest-paying sectors of our economy - retail trade and health and business services -while jobs in the higher-paying manufacturing sector have declined by 620,000.

Even during the Administration of Jimmy Carter our economy fared better: manufacturing jobs increased by 1.3 million, and only 42 percent of new jobs were in the lowest-paying sectors. Similarly, part-time jobs have increased by 704,000 since President Reagan took office, compared with a decline of 319,000 under President Carter. The average annual job creation was higher during the Carter Administration than under the Reagan Administration.

The 5.2 percent unemployment rate that you cite masks the true nature of unemployment in our economy: 24 million part-time workers who are counted as fully employed in determining the unemployment rate and 6 million more people who want jobs but don't fulfill the requirements set by the Labor Department to be counted as unemployed.

The results of the Reagan record on jobs are reflected in the latest poverty data (for 1986). Thirty-two million Americans live in poverty. Three million of these worked year round, and nine million were employed during the year.

The President may owe his night in the sun to victories in promoting the interests of the rich and the military - not to any achievements for this country's working poor and middle class. DAVID DEMBO WARD MOREHOUSE New York, Aug. 19, 1988
The writers are, respectively, the program coordinator and president of the Council on International and Public Affairs.
